direction.raw_text: . PRISON CEMETERY -- DAY A handful of people are gathered in an open field under a fierce Mississippi sun. A couple of young inmates, JAKE and LEON, lean on their shovels. They are waiting to bury two identical CASKETS with inmate numbers stenciled on the pinewood lids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rests the butt of his rifle on the ground and takes a long, healthy pull from his canteen. He offers it to the PRISON CHAPLAIN, who is much obliged. SUPERINTENDENT BILL BURKE, a 40-year-old black man, glances at his watch and loosens his tie. Sure is hot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: an elderly white woman in a nurse's uniform, stands behind WILLIE LONG, an ancient inmate sleeping peacefully in a wheelchair. She readjusts an umbrella to shield the old black man from the blistering sun. Burke dabs his forehead with a handkerchief. He gives the nod to the chaplain, who steps forward and cracks his bible. The men remove their hats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young inmates plunge their shovels into the dirt. One by one, the mourners head back toward a prison van parked on a nearby dirt road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leaves Willie alone with Jake and Leon. He rolls his chair up to the edge of the graves and gazes at the pinewood caskets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie pulls a bottle of moonshine from his jacket and takes a swig in their honor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie passes the bottle to Leon, who takes a swig and winces from the unexpected kick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie holds up the bottle, checking the clarity of the liquor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In accordance with the regulations of the State of Mississippi, we gather here today to lay to rest the remains of inmates R. Gibson, number 4316, and C. Banks, number 4317. Ashes to ashes, dust to dust. May God have mercy on their souls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead, fellas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come back for you in a little while, Willie...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These two guys friends of yours, old man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We spent some time together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do I get the feeling when you say some time, you mean some time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was already here a good many years when they came in in 1932.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ? That's like, that's like...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sixty-five years ago. They always said the farm couldn't hold 'em forever. Looks like you're finally free, boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, the dude's holdin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, old-timer, hook the brothers up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell of a way to get out. Heard they burned up in that fire yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I seen the bodies before they sealed 'em up. Them fellas sizzled up good. Looked like some shit from the X- Files. (taking a swig from the bottle) Damn, that shit's nasty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray's special recipe. He always had exacting standards where the hooch was concerned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were they, bootleggers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: holds up a similar bottle of liquor to a light over a door. Music comes from within. He takes a swig and stashes the bottle in his belt. He adjusts his tie, polishes his shoes on the back of his pants and raps on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SPANKY'S -- NIGHT The speakeasy is jumping, jammed with people. Up on stage a hot JAZZ BAND is playing backup for a seductive CHANTEUSE. Well-heeled PATRONS enter through doors near the stage. In the back, at the end of a long hallway, a BOUNCER cracks open the door and Ray squeezes inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray heads inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray slides through the crowd, pausing at the bar to nibble on the neck of a COCKTAIL WAITRESS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She carries a tray of drinks into the crowd. Ray shakes his head in wonderment at her departing form. The BARKEEP steps up as Ray pulls out his bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disregarding the warning, Ray tilts the bottle back. Shaking his head, the barkeep moves on to a paying customer. Ray's eyes follow a bottle of French Champagne as it is delivered to a nearby table. Here sits the straight-laced CLAUDE BANKS with his girlfriend, DAISY. She's enjoying the show. He's polishing the silverware. The WAITER pours two glasses of champagne and leaves the bottle on ice. Claude regards his glass skeptically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daisy thinks she does. She leans in, eyes twinkling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: French Champagne shoots out of Claude's nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude leans in to kiss Daisy on the lips. She offers her cheek. He departs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, Ray. Not tonight. Spanky's not happy with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Spanky here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what's the problem?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do yourself a favor and find another place where they let you in the front door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But this is where the action is and I have to be where the action is. Look, when your old lady wanted those alligator shoes, didn't I come through for you? Ain't she stepping in style now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, alright then. What do you think about this new tie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sharp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I look good tonight. And I feel lucky, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone asks, it wasn't me who let you in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't even try it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When do you get off?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I get off at two, but you ain't never getting off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't drink that in here, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sure can't drink that watered-down swill you're serving. Give me a glass of ice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't give you a glass of ice. I can't give you anything until you pay your damn tab.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the kind of money they charge here, you'd think they could hire somebody to actually wash the dishes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claude. Here's to your new job down at the bank. I always knew you'd make something of yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know what I'm going to buy with my first pay check?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Season tickets to the Yankees. Right there on the first base line. (off her disappointment) What's wrong, baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was hoping you were gonna say an engagement ring, Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Engagement ring!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what respectable folks do. Get a job, get married, start having babies. That's what you want, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure it is. I just don't see any reason to rush into things. Damn, look at this shirt. I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray watches Claude make a beeline for the men's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEN'S ROOM -- NIGHT Claude steps into the bathroom and approaches the sink. A big hand falls on his shoulder and yanks him backwards into a stall...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STALL -- NIGHT Claude is shoved down on the toilet by two BAG MEN in suits. Suddenly, it's crowded in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They rifle through Claude's jacket and quickly find his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They toss back his empty wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stall door swings shut as the bag men depart.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Congratulations, Claude. We understand you finally got yourself a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Guess that means you can pay Mr. Riley the fifty bucks you owe him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now wait a second, guys. I've got a bill to pay out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Twenty-two dollars. Not bad for a start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, fellas, that's two weeks pay. I'm here with my girl. You gotta leave me something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 How about your legs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My legs? Those are good, I'll keep the legs...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SPANKY'S -- NIGHT On his way into the Men's Room, Ray squeezes past the bag men on their way out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEN'S ROOM -- NIGHT Glancing around, Ray spots Claude's feet under the stall door. He steps up to the sink, washes his hands and takes a towel from the ATTENDANT. Scanning the assortment of grooming products, he selects a bottle of cologne and takes a sniff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the attendent bends down to retrieve a bottle of the good stuff, Ray palms a coin from the tip basket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray offers the quarter, a gesture of uncommon generosity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray pats the cologne on his face. A toilet flushes and Claude steps over to the sink. Ray catches his eye in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray throws his arms around Claude, deftly snatching his wallet. Claude extracts himself from Ray's embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude straightens his jacket and heads for the door. Ray stashes the stolen wallet in his jacket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (displeased) You have any of that French stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here you go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep the change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, thank you, sir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't I know you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I do. What's your name again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claude Banks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claude Banks. How could I forget that? You've got to remember me. Ray Gibson. We went to high school together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You went to Monroe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beaming) That's right! Good old Monroe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I went to Jefferson, so you must have a different Claude Banks in mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, man. My mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SPANKY'S -- NIGHT On the stage, the chanteuse has downshifted into a sultry number about back-door lovers and broken dreams. Ray steps out of the men's room and is instantly collared by BULLETHEAD, a man who makes his living being large and threatening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pressed up against the wall, Ray reaches into his jacket and produces Claude's wallet. Bullethead snatches it, inspects it and is not impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stuffs the wallet back into Ray's jacket and hustles Ray out the back door past the bouncer who let him in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Watch the threads, Bullethead. If this is about my tab, I've got it covered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This ain't about your tab, Ray. You've got bigger problems than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that Ray Gibson? Who the hell let him in here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Claude returns to the table where Daisy is sipping champagne. He takes the glass out of her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waiter presents Claude with the bill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, honey, let's get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm having a good time...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sir, I believe you forgot this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The bill. Of course, the bill. We couldn't leave without paying the bill. Especially such an incredibly large bill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . VAN -- NIGHT Claude is shoved into the back of the van and the doors are slammed behind him. He bangs and shouts, but it's no use.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray is stretched out against the back wall. Claude is knocked to the floor as the van lurches into motion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray swigs from his bottle and offers it to Claude, who isn't interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Busted, Claude snatches the bottle and carefully wipes off the neck before tilting it high. Ray gets a good chuckle out of this straight cat in the bow tie.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Save your energy, Claude. You're gonna need it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, this belongs to you. (tossing Claude his wallet) It was empty when I found it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good old Monroe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I want to know is what happened to your cush between the time that you got up from the table and when I caught up with you in the Johnny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see where that's any of your business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did those two muscle heads shake you down? Swear I've seen them down at the track with Sure-shot Riley. That's it, ain't it? A gambling debt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where they taking us, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably to Spanky's headquarters down at the pier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, I'm looking forward to meeting this Spanky. Give me a chance to straighten out this whole mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't wait to see that. You slay me, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PIER -- NIGHT The van pulls into a the loading bay of a warehouse at the end of a short pier on the Harlem River.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WAREHOUSE -- NIGHT Bullethead and a HENCHMAN pull Ray and Claude from the back of the van. They find themselves in a dark warehouse filled with crates of contraband.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude shoves his hands under his armpits at the sound of approaching FOOTSTEPS echoing across the vast space. Claude and Ray peer into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) What are they gonna do to us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You? Dine and ditch, right? (Claude nods) Over ten bucks? (he nods again) You're probably looking at a thumb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A thumb? What do you mean, like cut it off? For ten bucks? (Ray nods) That include the tip?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (from the darkness) You picked the wrong night to fuck with me, Ray. I just lost three men and a truck full of Canadian whiskey. You know what that kind of thing does to my business? It makes me want to lash out and hurt somebody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: emerges into the light. He uses a small silver spoon to take an ample snort of cocaine into each nostril. He glances at Claude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spanky holds up a hand, silencing Claude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude protests loudly as Bullethead and the henchman bind his hands and feet. Spanky turns to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The goons hoist Claude up on another pulley and dangle him head first over a hole in the floor. Several feet down, the Harlem River laps against the wooden pylons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shrugging, Ray pinches his nose and puffs out his cheeks. The goons release the rope and Claude plunges into the water. Spanky turns back to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The henchman yanks on the rope. Claude emerges from the hole, gasping for breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The henchman releases the rope, sending Claude back into the water. Ray reaches into his jacket. Bullethead pulls a gun and presses it into Ray's temple. Ray gives him a look and cautiously pulls out his bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray tosses him the bottle. Spanky uncorks, sniffs, samples the goods. He's impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once again, the henchman yanks on the rope and Claude comes up sucking air desperately. He releases the rope, submerging Claude for a third time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spanky considers the terms. Can he afford to trust Ray? Can he afford not to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray glances around. The pulley rope is still twitching in the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spanky sees Ray's point. He nods to the henchman, who hoists Claude's limp body out of the water and onto the cement. Spanky plants a foot on Claude's chest and applies pressure. A geyser of Harlem River water shoots from Claude's mouth as he sputters back to life.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's he? Friend of yours, Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never saw this man before tonight. He's a lowlife degenerate who lurks in bathrooms. I'm a professional man, an upstanding citizen. I go to church on Sunday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Failure to pay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rattled) Look, Mr. Johnson, you seem like a reasonable man. I got a good job starts Monday. I'll pay you back with my first pay check. With interest. I don't want to tell you how to conduct your business, but if you cut off my finger you won't get jack. Working an adding machine, I gotta be whole. (his fingers dancing over imaginary keys) I need my thumbs and all my fingers for praying and doing good...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The choirboy wants to keep his fingers. Who am I to argue? Drop him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drop him? What does drop him mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gotta lotta balls showing your face around my club. If a man's gonna run numbers on my side of Broadway, you think he'd have the common sense to keep a low profile. But not Ray Gibson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, not down there! That water's filthy! Help me out here, man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to drown that fella, Spanky. You already scared him half to death. He didn't know who he was fucking with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you do. What does that say about you, Ray? What does that say about me? I've given you a lot of leeway over the years on account of your father. But he didn't last long enough to teach you the meaning of the word respect so I guess I'm gonna have to school you myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Spank, I'm just trying to get by here. You remember how it was when you were starting out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was supposed to wear this suit on Monday!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that, some of your bathtub brew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Puerto Rican rum. See for yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where'd you get this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Comes up the Mississippi. I can get more. A lot more. I was thinking about going into business for myself, but under the circumstances, I'd be willing to take on a partner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm interested. Keep talking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I need is the front money and a truck. I could be back in two, three days tops if I had somebody to share the driving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you fuck me on this one, I'll spare no expense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Understood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, Ray, you've got a deal. Pick your man and get going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take the little choirboy, if you don't mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I was you, I'd want somebody who can handle himself in a tight spot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just want somebody who won't put a bullet in my back once the truck is full.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For your sake, I hope you can drive. Somebody give him some dry clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA MOVES UP the side of the old Ford truck to find Claude sitting pensively in the passenger seat.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE SPINNING WHEEL OF A TRUCK

direction.raw_text: Ray palms the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tight-lipped, Claude shifts in his seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If Claude does like it, he's not letting on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat of silence. Ray laughs to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray pulls out his pocket watch. A mechanical tune plays as he checks the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray stuffs his daddy's watch back in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me about that hot sketch you were hypin' last night. She was a choice bit of calico. You two been seeing each other a long time? Gonna slap the handcuffs on her and stroll down the aisle one of these days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes I wish I could find me a sheba to settle down with. Suppose I'm just a tomcat by nature. (trying to fill the silence) This little rum run is gonna seriously improve my relationship with Spanky. He's a good man to have on your side. He's got the capital and the connections. That's what you got to have in that business. Spanky's place is pretty plush, but one of these days I'm gonna open up my own establishment. Ray's Boom-Boom Room. You like that? Ray's Boom-Boom Room. That's in the groove, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, daddy-o. You haven't said a word since we started. Least you could do is make some friendly conversation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, man, I don't want friendly conversation. I don't want to be your friend. I've seen your friends and I don't like them. I just want to do this thing and get back to New York in time to start my job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Start your job? What kind of job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if you must know, bank teller at First Federal of Manhattan. I'm responsible for keeping track of hundreds, occasionally thousands of dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's some long green.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn straight, it is. I got my own set of keys because I'm supposed to open up. So if I ain't there 8 a.m. Monday morning, there's gonna be hell to pay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, tell me what's so funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Bank teller. Sounds like ladies work to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, maybe I should dig around in other people's clothes for money. It's obviously been highly successful for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, you'd be surprised what you find in other people's pockets. Just gotta avoid them deadbeat bank tellers. Get you every time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't start out to be a bank teller. I was gonna be a ballplayer. Even had an offer to play short for the Newark Eagles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you take it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Negro League don't pay so good. And you're always on the road. That don't wash with Daisy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gave up baseball to be a bank teller? I can't latch on to that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At some point a man's got to get serious about his future. I'm sure you have no idea what I'm talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're talking about giving up baseball to be a bank teller.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bank teller's just a start. I got plans. Real plans. Not opening some Zoom-Boom Room. This time next year I'll be a loan officer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A loan officer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, a loan officer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you mean, if I needed some jack to get my nightclub up and running, I'd have to hype some square like you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would I get a loan, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You need collateral.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (re: watch) Like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That thing? Who'd you steal it from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daddy gave me this watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? Who'd he steal it from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daddy is dead so watch your mouth. You can say what you want about me, but don't be dragging my daddy into it. This watch means the world to me. Solid gold. Keeps perfect time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like a fake to me. Loan denied!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, go chase yourself. I'll take my business elsewhere. And for future reference, you are no longer welcome at Ray's Boom-Boom Room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no Boom-Boom Room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When there is, you can forget about it. And I swear to God, you ever talk about my daddy again I'm gonna kick your bank-telling, loan-denying ass, you got me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oooh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I liked you better when you kept your trap shut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ROADSIDE DINER -- DAY The truck veers off the highway and jerks to a halt in front of the rundown establishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROADSIDE DINER -- DAY A dozen WHITE FOLKS look up as Ray and Claude push through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing but sullen stares from all corners of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude tugs Ray towards the door but Ray won't be dissuaded. He boldly addresses a YOUNG MAN in an apron behind the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy's MAMA sets a piping hot pie on the back counter and steps up next to her son. She casts a disparaging glance at Claude's suit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude considers the sign she's pointing to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude jabs him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude starts tugging Ray toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Diner patrons stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude narrows his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Resolved, Claude stomps over to the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude lays down a dollar bill. Mama casually pulls a shotgun from under the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gives the whole place a cool once-over as Claude pulls him out the door. Mama turns to Billy, still studying the stitching on his shirt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Man, something smells good in here. How's everybody doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) Maybe we oughta find another place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you kidding? Tell me you don't want a slice of that pie right over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must have left my appetite outside, which is where I think we ought to be right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Billy. We'd like some coffee and a couple of slices of that homemade pie you've got advertised.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How you know my name's Billy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It says so right there on your shirt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glancing down) That what that says?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you boys can read so good, how come you missed that sign in the window?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean this sign? The one that says "No Coloreds Allowed." That's a good question. Ray, how come we missed the sign?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, ma'am, we've been driving all day. We'd just like to purchase one of those pies and we'll be on our way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those are whites-only pies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got any nigger pies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any fool could see those are whites- only, not-for-blacks, come-on-let's- get-the-fuck-outta-here pies. Thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) Thanks for backing me up here, Uncle Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) Don't Uncle Claude me. You get a load of those crackers? Couldn't be a mouthful of teeth among the bunch of 'em. Why you want to pick a fight with people like that for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're soft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said you're soft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, man, don't ever call me that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I call it like I see it, and what I see is definitely soft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright. You want some pie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I want some pie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay then, I'm gonna walk over to that counter and get us some fucking pie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, ma'am, I bet a brick will turn that one right there into a colored pie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I bet this right here will turn you into a colored pie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, Ray, I think we can go now. Much obliged...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be concentrating so hard, baby. You're liable to seize yourself again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DOCKS -- NIGHT The truck rolls up to the waters edge. Ray kills the engine and flashes the lights twice. In the passenger seat, Claude is fast asleep. After a few moments, a FAT MAN appears, shining a flashlight into the cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray cocks an eyebrow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How you doing? We're looking for Slim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You found him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DOCKS -- NIGHT Under cover of darkness, a couple of MEN finish loading crates into the bed of the truck. Ray and Claude keep their eyes peeled for the law. Down by the river, they can see lights and hear music from a district of rowdy juke joints. SLIM steps up, wiping his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray pulls out a wad and slaps it in Slim's sweaty palm. The fat man starts counting it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slim slips into the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A look of excitement crosses Claude's face, but he quickly shakes it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exasperated, Ray stuffs a few bills into Claude's pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Left alone, Claude mutters and kicks at the dirt. He leans against the truck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's it, fellas. Thirty six cases of Puerto Rico's finest. At five bucks a case, that's $180.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man, that music is hot. What goes on down there, Slim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's Natchez-under-the-Hill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blacks welcome there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Green's the only color that matters under the hill. They got gambling, girls. You oughta check it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe we will. Nice meeting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice meeting you? You've been here before, haven't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What gave you that idea?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I don't know, maybe because our lives depend on it, I just sort of thought you knew what you were doing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get all agitated on me. I bought a bottle of rum from a couple of dudes, I heard 'em talking...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me get this straight. We drove all the way down to Klan country 'cause you heard a couple of guys talking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you complaining about? It worked out. Everything's cool. Now, come on, let's head down there and see what's shaking. We deserve a little reward.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dubious) Reward?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are people down there having fun. I want to be one of them. I want you to be one of them. On Monday you can be a bank teller if you want, but tonight you're a bootlegger with a truck full of Puerto Rican rum and a fistful of cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's gas money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's your gas money. You stay here and watch the truck. And don't worry, I've got the keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUKE JOINT -- NIGHT Ray emerges from the woods and heads down the hill toward the juke joint. Claude hustles up next to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just gonna keep an eye on you, make sure you don't do nothing stupid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUKE JOINT -- NIGHT A ramshackle den of iniquity on the banks of the Mississippi. The band is laying down some serious Delta blues, creating an inviting atmosphere for sin and moral corruption. On a far side of the room, Ray is playing poker with some LOCALS. He seems to be having a bad night. WINSTON HANCOCK, a formidable black man, sweeps in another big pot and puffs happily on his cigar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perched on a stool, Claude shoots a dark look at Ray and motions for the door. Ray waves him off and returns to his game. Claude becomes aware of a soft, young female hand on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Against his better judgement, Claude's gaze follows the long, slender arm up past a bare shoulder and settles on SYLVIA'S angelic face. He is struck dumb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The drinks arrive. She places a shot glass in Claude's reluctant hand. She winks provocatively and slowly pours the whiskey down her throat. Instinctively, Claude tosses back his shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bartender refills their glasses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen you in here before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring at the hand) That's because I've never been here before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Sylvia. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't you remember your own name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know it begins with a "C"...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Mr. "C", how about buying a girl a drink? (to the bartender) Two bourbons.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I really shouldn't. I gotta keep an eye on my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He looks like he can take care of himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claude. That's my name. Claude. That's never happened before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're cute. You have any money, Claude?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ten dollars. But I need it to get home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why would you want to go home? It's so early.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Winston considers his cards, hardly looking up as a WAITRESS lays down a cocktail napkin and sets a drink down on top of it. He glances at Ray, who casually considers his cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dealer tosses Ray a couple of cards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take two.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- Ray fans his cards to reveal a full house. After considering the other players at the table, Ray pushes what's left of his money into the center of the table. The three other PLAYERS fold with disgust. Winston squints long and hard at Ray, then pushes everything he has into the center of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winston reaches into his jacket and throws down some more money on the pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray checks his cards again. He looks at the pot, it's a lot of money. With this hand, there's no way he can lose. He places his daddy's pocket watch on top of the pile. Winston checks the time piece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray lays down his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray sits back, stunned. Winston rakes in his winnings. The game is over for the night. The three other players head to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winston tosses a silver dollar to Ray, who snatches it out of the air. Winston drops his hat on his head and moves through the crowd and out the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray shakes his head. Carefully, she begins to clear the table. Suddenly, he grabs her wrist. Winston's glass tips over. Ray flips over the cocktail napkin to reveal an extra pile of cards.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And while we're at it, let's sweeten the pot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like my sugar bowl's empty, Mr. Hancock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reaching for the pot) That's just too damn bad, ain't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, hang on, slick. I ain't through with you yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'll cover it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Full boat, ladies doing the paddling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four threes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't take it too hard, New York. Have a round on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I get you something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like he had a whole lot of nothing in his hand until you came along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wrenching free) You're hurting my arm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . JUKE JOINT -- NIGHT Ray dashes into the street, glancing both ways. No sign of Winston. Damn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BACK ALLEY -- NIGHT Winston produces Ray's pocket watch and pops it open. A smile crosses his face as the mechanical tune plays. A sheriff's sedan rounds a corner, illuminating Winston in its headlights. The car pulls up and SHERIFF WARREN PIKE steps out. Distinguished by a casual cruelness, he's a young white man who loves his uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winston tries to move past Pike, but the sheriff blocks his path with a night stick. As Winston backs off, another squad car pulls up behind him. TWO DEPUTIES step from the car, guns drawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pike slams Winston with his club, sending the black man to his knees. As Winston struggles back to his feet, a stiletto flashes and he lunges for the sheriff, slashing his cheek. The deputies grab Winston from behind, holding him by both arms. The long knife clatters to ground. Pike touches his face, examining the blood on his fingers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If it isn't Winston Hancock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought we agreed that you were gonna leave town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tried to leave, Sheriff Pike. But your wife begged me to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just committed suicide, boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BORDELLO HALLWAY -- NIGHT Ray walks slowly down the hallway to Room 13. He is about to knock when he hears the sound of lovemaking from within.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SYLVIA'S BEDROOM -- NIGHT Ray opens the door and peeks in. Sylvia's on top and in charge. Claude is concentrating real hard. Ray smiles to himself and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . JUKE JOINT -- NIGHT Claude hitches up his suspenders as he comes down the stairs. He finds Ray having a drink at the now-empty bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray. I've been looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guess we better get going, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still got that ten dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, not exactly. See, I met this girl. Real nice girl. God-fearing girl. Her name's Sylvia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That jelly you were talking to right here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's in a tight spot. Her mama needs this operation, and they ain't got the money for it. Their church took up a collection but they were still short...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you made a generous contribution.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What can I say? When the spirit moves me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was mighty charitable of you, Claude. Looks like we both got fucked tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: While you were upstairs doing God's work, I was getting jack-legged by a fool with four threes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You lost all our money in a card game?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He even got my daddy's watch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck that cheap-ass watch -- (off Ray's glare) I mean, how the hell are we gonna get home without any money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've still got 36 cases of rum. That's better than money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BACK ALLEY -- NIGHT Ray and Claude head down the alley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, the bloodied figure of Winston Hancock lurches from the shadows and grabs Claude by the lapels. Claude is too scared to scream, staggering backward. But the man's grip loosens and he slips to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns back to find Claude trembling with fear and covered in blood. He just points down. Ray eyes widen. He kneels down and turns Winston's body over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much to Claude's horror, Ray starts rifling through Winston's pockets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, the glare of two bright headlights from a pickup truck freeze Ray and Claude in a guilty tableau. FIVE WHITE MEN appear at the end of the alley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gingerly releases Winston's lifeless body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude and Ray hoist Winston's body to its feet. The man raises his lantern, takes a closer look at Winston's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude check for themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, the men all have guns. And they're pointed at Ray and Claude.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You sure the truck's this way? (looking over his shoulder) I swear it was back that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (croaking) Ray... Yo, Ray...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think he's hurt pretty bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, man, I've never seen a dead body before!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think you're doing?! The man's been dead for two seconds! Don't you have any respect?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It ain't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What ain't there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daddy's watch. This is the dude I was telling you about --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's going on here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong with that one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Him? He's just drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, nobody puts 'em away like old what's-his-name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Winston. His name's Winston.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Ray, better get Winston back to the truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This fella looks dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you look at that, Ray. Winston up and died on us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell with him then. If he can't share the driving, he can't ride in the truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He can ride with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So can you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NATCHEZ JAIL -- NIGHT In a holding cell, Ray tests the window bars. Solid. Meanwhile, Claude sits on a cot brooding darkly. Through the bars, we see the rednecks laughing and passing around a bottle of bootleg rum with the DEPUTY on duty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jailhouse door opens and Sheriff Pike walks in. He pauses to give the prisoners the once-over. There's a fresh bandage over the cut on his cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pike winks at his deputy, then turns to regard the prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pike turns his back on the prisoners and checks the time on a gold pocket watch -- Ray's pocket watch. But from his cell, Ray can't hear the mechanical tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the cell, Claude turns to Ray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Man, this is gonna delay everything. Spanky's gonna be pissed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Spanky's gonna be pissed? Poor Spanky. Fuck Spanky! What the hell kind of a name is Spanky, anyway? You're responsible for this situation. I blame you for everything. If it wasn't for you, I'd be home having a hot meal right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it wasn't for me, you'd be washing up on the beach at Coney Island right now. (mocking Claude)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: need all my thumbs and fingers for praying and doing good."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we have here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Billy Bob and the boys found them down down under the hill with Winston Hancock. He was dead. Looks like murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like they was running rum. Got thirty six cases of evidence out back. You want I should call in the federal prosecutor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's not drag the feds into this. I can think of better uses for that rum than letting it collect dust in some government warehouse up in Nashville.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides, why bother with bootlegging when we got us a clear cut case of murder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, sheriff. As we explained to your associate here, there's been a mistake. We didn't kill anybody. Now, as for the bootlegging, we happen to work for a very important man in New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. Does the name Spanky Johnson mean anything to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Afraid not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Johnson is very well connected. If you were to let us go, I guarantee he would show you his appreciation, if you know what I mean.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you offering me a bribe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just trying to pay the toll on the road to justice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may be able to buy your way out of trouble up in New York City, but down here we take murder seriously.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, man, how many times we gotta tell you people, we didn't kill that guy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if that's the case, then you don't have anything to worry about, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Time to get home to the missus. See y'all in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man's gotta point. We're innocent, after all. I just gotta get a good night's sleep on this filthy mattress. Keep our heads on straight, stay cool, what's the worst thing that could happen to us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COURTROOM -- DAY The CAMERA Scorseses in on the JUDGE'S face...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gavel comes down with a thundering crash. Stunned, Ray and Claude resist the BAILIFFS' efforts to remove them from the courtroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue to protest loudly as they are dragged bodily through the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Life!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Life?! How long is life? We were just walking back to the truck. We didn't do nothing! Fuck life!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Life?! What's life mean? There's no way I can do life. I got a job starts Monday morning!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE -- DAY Blues music kicks in as a prison transport bus rolls down a dirt road cutting through the bleak Mississippi Delta.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a white prison sergeant, sits behind the wheel. A shot gun hangs within easy reach. The CAMERA MOVES BACK past grim-faced PRISONERS with their hands and feet shackled. We arrive at Ray and Claude sitting in grim silence as the bus lurches along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PRISON -- DAY The bus veers off the country road and passes under a sign: MISSISSIPPI STATE PENITENTIARY. Sgt. Dillard's voice PLAYS OVER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude stare out the window, getting their first look at the harsh reality that awaits them. Cotton fields stretch to the horizon in every direction. HOE-GANGS till the earth under the watchful gaze of TRUSTY SHOOTERS...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Along the road, CONVICTS cast hard looks at the new men as the cart passes. A WHITE SERGEANT on horseback shifts his rifle and casually spits tobacco juice in the dirt...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Welcome to the farm. Here you will be provided with ample opportunity to repay your debt to society through the rigors of hard labor...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) In between harvest and planting season we got fields need clearing, roads need building and ditches need digging. You will eat only what you can grow. Your crop don't come in, you'll go hungry. If you die, don't worry 'bout us none. We'll find somebody to replace you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 -- DAY A low-slung, single-story bunkhouse surrounded by a dirt yard. Two shooter shacks sit at diagonal corners of the yard. In each shack, two trusties with rifles keep vigilant watch over the camp. SGT. FRED DILLARD paces down the line of new men as HOPPIN' BOB, an uncommonly ugly trusty, unlocks their leg irons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard plucks a hat off one of the new prisoners and tosses it over the gun line. SHOTS ring out from the nearest shack. The hat is torn to shreds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard puts a cigarette in his mouth. Hoppin' Bob is right there with the flame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nodding to Bob, Dillard saunters off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude share a look. Self-consciously, the men begin to undress.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This here is Camp 8. Camp 8 is for incorrigibles, so whatever you've done to get here, believe me, we're not impressed. You new men are probably noticing that we have no fences here at Camp 8. We don't need no fences, we have the gun line. It runs from shack to shack clear around the yard. You are now inside the gun line. If you step outside the gun line without my permission, you will be shot. If you trip and fall over the gun line, you will be shot. If you spit, if you pee, if you stick your ass out and take a dump over the gun line, you will be shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of my trusties puts a bullet in you when you're trying to run, I'm liable to give him a pardon for saving me the trouble of tracking you down, so you can bet their aim is true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name is Sgt. Dillard. In the unlikely event that you need to address me, you call me boss. You already met this handsome fella right here. Hoppin' Bob's my ace boon coon. You run afoul of Hoppin' Bob, you run afoul of me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: New men, strip down!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- DAY Double bunks line the walls, with a footlocker for each inmate. As usual, there's a poker game going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All activity comes to a halt as the new men shuffle into the cage wearing their prison-issue "ring-arounds." Hoppin' Bob slams the metal doors shut behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The INCORRIGIBLES hungrily eye the new men in total silence. Claude sticks close to Ray as they shuffle toward their assigned bunks. The CAMERA SETTLES on a much younger WILLIE LONG.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, ladies, got some fresh meat for ya!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We ain't got no wallflowers at Camp 8. Everybody gotta dance eventually. But don't worry, they won't try nothing tonight. That would take all of the fun outta the courtship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY ROAD -- MORNING The inmates jump down from the mule cart and grab hoes and shovels. Because he can't count, Hoppin' Bob keeps track of the men using a system all his own -- a PEBBLE in his pocket for each man. Dillard stands by with his shotgun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Got three miles of ditch to clear today. Let's keep it moving!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DITCH -- DAY The men of Camp 8 labor under the brutal mid-day sun. JANGLE LEG, a handsome, muscular man, sings a verse to set the work tempo. Up and down the line, a mighty chorus responds. The CAMERA FINDS Ray and Claude swinging pick axes, sweating profusely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude stops to catch his breath and take off his shirt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't believe this before Abe jive. I didn't go to night school to sing in no Mississippi Boys Choir!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't do that if I was you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up. It's too damn hot. What do you know, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rings out. Claude hits the ground as a bullet kicks up some dust nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude looks up to see Dillard cracking pistachio nuts as Hoppin' Bob puts another round in the chamber of his rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annoyed, Dillard jabs the butt of his rifle into Ray's solar plexus. Ray sinks to his knees in the dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard swaggers off, dogged at the heels by the ever faithful Hoppin' Bob. Resigned, Ray and Claude return to their labor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Told ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why ain't his pick swinging?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (echoing) Why ain't that pick swinging?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too hot, boss. I'm tired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He says it's too hot, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too hot, huh? Well, you tell that lazy jiggaboo the state of Mississippi ain't interested in his meteorological assessments.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen up, jiggaboo! State of Mississippi ain't interested in your... in your... (off Dillard's look) metropolitan assets!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell him the state of Mississippi is only interested in getting this ditch cleared by sundown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: State of Mississippi wants this ditch cleared by sundown. You got that?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got it... boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He don't sound like he's from 'round here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's from New York City. That one, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: New York. That's up north, ain't it? They'll find we do things different down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We noticed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like we got a couple of live ones. How long these boys in for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Judge gave 'em the long ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Life, huh? They step outta line again, we'll shorten up that sentence real fast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DITCH -- DAY The men rest in the ditch as BISCUIT, a slight inmate with a red bandanna tied around his head, dispenses water, one ladle per man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie exchanges two cigarettes for a second ladle. POKER FACE pulls a crumpled envelope from his shirt. His expression never changes, hence the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray unfolds the letter and scans it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners express their condolences. "Sorry, man." "That's some bad news." "I know you loved Bo like a brother..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More sympathy from the men. "Ooh. Twice in one letter." "Rough break, Poker Face..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Relief all around. "Thank goodness."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Bad luck, man." "That's harsh..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners share dark looks. Ray folds up the letter and hands it back to Poker Face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "No, man, we're good." The men shake their heads and return letters and cards to their pockets. Jangle Leg nods and switches places with one of the convicts, parking next to Claude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they shake, Jangle Leg inspects Claude's hand thoroughly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude snatches back his hand and gives Jangle Leg a hard look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the men grab their tools and return to work, Claude leans over to Ray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Drink it up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Either of you new fellas know how to read? I've had this letter four months now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't read? None of these guys can read?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last fella who could read made parole 'round Christmas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't even know who this is from.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, gimme that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's from your mama's neighbor, Mrs. Tidwell. She thought you oughta know that your second cousin Bo died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And your other cousin, Sally, on your daddy's side, she died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Apparently, your sister died.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jenny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it says Marleen here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, wait, looks like Jenny died, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then it goes on for a while about how the crop didn't come in on accounta the frost. (flips over the page) She finishes up with something about a tornado and how your mama and your daddy died in that. But don't worry none. She'll take care of the dog. That is, if it gets over the worms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Appreciate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody else need anything read?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How you doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever done time before?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You kidding? I've been in and out of prison my entire life. Mostly in. I'm hard-core.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you won't have no problem making the adjustment. You need anything, help of any kind, gimme a holler. Name's Jangle Leg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Preciate it. Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Soft and supple. Like a lady's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes narrowing) I try to moisturize regularly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (over his shoulder) Hey, Jangle Leg, what'd I tell you about pitching woo on the job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, Cap'n.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Break's over! Back to work!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you think they call him Jangle Leg?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody just told me he wins the three-legged race every year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He does it all by himself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MESS HALL -- DUSK Wincing with each movement and covered in grime from the day's labors, the new men bring up the back of the chow line. COOKIE, the grub-slinger, slaps a large dollop of an unidentifiable substance onto Ray's tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another prisoner lays down some tobacco and gets a juicy steak. Ray grabs a hunk of corn bread and makes his way to the back of the room. Claude steps up, holds out his tray for Cookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disappointed, Claude turns to discover that the only seat left is next to Ray. Scowling, he limps toward it. Jangle Leg's eyes follow Claude as he approaches the table. Biscuit smacks him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude sits down and promptly goes to work scraping his burnt toast with his knife. The irritating sound slowly brings the entire room to dead silence. All eyes fall on Claude. Scratch, scratch, scratch...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cookie glowers and takes a seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the room returns to normal, Claude starts polishing his fork with his shirttail. Irritated, Ray shoots him a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Undeterred, Claude breathes on his fork and polishes it some more. Disgusted, Ray pushes aside his plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole table waits expectantly for their reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the end of the table, GOLDMOUTH, a hulking specimen, snarls menacingly, flashing a glittering set of teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then, Goldmouth stands up, casting a shadow over Claude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude looks up, considering his options.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray picks up his corn bread and takes a huge bite out of it, rolling his eyes with enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks at the faces around the room, smiles broadly. Goldmouth is getting embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners begin to laugh. Ray's got them now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Creamed chip beef on toast. Except we're outta beef, so I had to improvise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't I get one of those steaks you got grilling back there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those are for trusties, unless you got thirty cents or two packs of cigs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, I don't like it when the food touches each other, so if you could just -- (SPLAT!)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: keep everything separate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eyes front, mister!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stepping up) Problem with the toast?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's fine now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop aggravating people. Just eat your food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This fork is filthy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fork is the least of your worries, Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me? Willie Long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you in for, Willie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a long story...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When he was 13 years old he killed a son-of-a-bitch with a claw hammer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They never proved that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What a second, you've been in here since you were thirteen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about you, Radio?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Armed robbery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn liar. Bitch killed his sister with an axe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was my half-sister. Shit, I ain't the son-of-a-bitch who poisoned my own parents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (protective) They deserved it. Very strict.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about you, Biscuit? You nearly skinned your poor old landlady alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least he didn't kill Santa Claus with his bare hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You killed Santa Claus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scolding) On Christmas Eve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wasn't the Santa Claus, he was just wearing the suit and ringing a bell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you guys do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I kinda lost track of how many people we killed that night. Must have been 15 or twenty -- not counting women and children. It was a real bloodbath. All that screaming...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pack of lies. Don't listen to him. We didn't kill nobody. We were railroaded. And we gonna prove that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He just blocked it out. Nigger's crazy. He's the one who did all the stabbing. He's capable of some heinous shit. (thumbing down the table) How 'bout him down there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goldmouth? They say he was born out back behind the shithouse. That's what they say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You all been here a long time. Doesn't anybody ever escape from this place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They run but they never get too far.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Couple years back, Cookie made it clear to Greenville.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Greenville, that the nearest town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nodding) It's a two-day walk if you don't get lost. Take a mighty cagey country boy to navigate the woods and bayous between here and there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those dogs they got can sniff a skid mark in your underpants from a half- mile off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, well, let's say you make it to Greenville. What's there, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Grandma Dodi's Pork Rib Joint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's where they nabbed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't even get to have my peach cobbler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The most important thing they got in Greenville is a train that heads up north.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, girl, you gonna eat your corn bread?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, man. I want you to have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait up there, Claude. You give that guy your corn bread and the next thing you know you'll be ironing his shirts and clipping his toenails.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I oughta eat your corn bread.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My corn bread? Oh no, my friend. I love corn bread.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought my mama made good corn bread but this is really something special.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who knew I'd have to come all the way down to this here prison, deep in the asshole of the great state of Mississippi, to find such a tasty piece of corn bread?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And who knew that in this great corn bread-making institution I'd come face to face with the biggest, ugliest, stinkiest, ugliest gold- mouthed negro in the entire world. Now get out of my face before I lose my appetite!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DUSK A punch sends Ray sprawling in the dust. Goldmouth looms over him. The incorrigibles form a circle around the combatants. Poker Face, the camp bookie, is taking all bets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goldmouth and Ray square off. Goldmouth swings, Ray ducks and counters with a swift jab to the gut. Goldmouth just flashes a shiny grin and clobbers Ray with a fist the size of a Thanksgiving turkey. Ray sinks to the dust. Radio drops down near him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray shakes his head and staggers back to his feet. He circles the big man and gets in a couple of good shots, much to the crowd's approval. Goldmouth shakes his head and wipes the blood from his nose. Now he's mad. He grabs Ray by the shirt and delivers a crushing blow. Ray reels backward into Cookie's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cookie shoves Ray back into the ring for more punishment. Claude emerges from the mess hall, munching on a piece of corn bread. He squeezes in between Poker Face and Willie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then Claude winces as Goldmouth delivers a jaw-crushing uppercut that knocks Ray on his back. Claude bristles under the incriminating looks coming at him from all directions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude crouches down as Ray rolls over on his stomach and pushes himself up onto all fours. His eyes are swollen shut, his face covered with blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray manages a smile and staggers to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goldmouth pulls back his fist and lets it fly. Ray hurtles through the crowd, collapsing in the dust. Willie steps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cookie, Radio and Poker Face raise Ray to his feet. Goldmouth slings him over his shoulder and carries him toward the bunkhouse. Dazed, Ray catches Claude's eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A quick elbow jab from Goldmouth and Ray is out for good. Disgusted with himself, Claude tosses what's left of the corn bread to the mangy dog, who makes short work of it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How you like your corn bread now, New York?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, New York, you can do better than that! Get up and show him how they do it in Harlem!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I appreciate you going to all this trouble over my corn bread. I don't get a lot of compliments in my line of work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your pal's getting the tar whipped out of him on your account.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many times I got to tell you? He ain't my pal. Besides, he looks like he knows what he's doing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, alright...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, I think you made your point, whatever that is. Maybe now's a good time to throw in the towel. You know what I'm saying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (slurring) Shit, Goldmouth. Back in New York, I know bitches who hit harder than you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man's taken enough of a beating. Let's get him inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got him good, huh, Claude? He won't be bothering us anytime soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wagging a finger) Shame, shame, that's your name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MESS HALL -- DAY On Sundays, the mess hall also serves as a chapel. From a makeshift pulpit, the blind REVEREND CLAY and his DAUGHTER lead the congregation of convicts in a rousing chorus of "Down by the Riverside."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY The gospel music filters into the yard, where the prisoners mingle with kinfolk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DILLARD'S HOUSE -- DAY MRS. DILLARD hums along with the gospel music as she places a couple of freshly-baked pies on the window sill to cool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY The CAMERA FINDS Claude and Daisy walking hand in hand toward a simple shack just beyond the gun line. This is the TONK HOUSE and Dillard is the gate keeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard considers Daisy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daisy gets the picture. She reaches into her purse and hands Dillard a couple of dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude takes Daisy's hand and leads her over the gun line.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Request permission to go to the tonk, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see no wedding ring, Banks. Conjugal visits are for married prisoners only.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think you could make an exception just this once, boss? She came all the way down from New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't need the Baptists on my back, but I suppose I could issue a temporary marriage license for a nominal fee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I now pronounce you man and wife. (calling to the shooter shack) Claude Banks going to the tonk!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ray watches Claude and Daisy step into the tonk house. Then he returns to a game of horseshoes, tossing a ringer. Nearby, Biscuit gives Jangle Leg a haircut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Radio looks up from a vacuum tube receiver he's busy repairing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hoppin' Bob calls to Ray from the gun line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns to find his MOTHER, a handsome woman in a floral dress, coming toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The incorrigibles elbow each other and repeat the name "Rayford" as Mama Gibson envelops her son in a fleshy embrace, smothering him with kisses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The motley crew gathers around, nodding politely. Goldmouth flashes a golden grin. Willie gallantly doffs his cap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama manages a half-hearted smile, clutching her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Biscuit sides up, fingering her dress.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Biscuit, when you're done with Jangle Leg, you think you could squeeze me in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thought you'd never ask. Biscuit needs some gravy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talking about a haircut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cost you a pair of nylons.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, Goldmouth don't believe me. Ain't it so they got trains up in New York City that run under the streets?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're called subways. A nickel will take you from one end of Manhattan to the other. Helluva ride, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, you ever been to the Cotton Club?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I've been to the Cotton Club. It's pretty sweet. But it don't hold a candle to the Boom Boom Room. That's where the real action is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the Boom Boom Room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's my joint. The swinginest nightclub in town.
