dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got your own nightclub?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, not yet. It's still in the planning stages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So it don't exist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just because it's in my mind, Goldmouth, don't mean it ain't real. Everything worth anything starts with a dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gibson! Got yourself a visitor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rayford!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here, mama?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard some things so I went to see Spanky Johnson. He told me what happened and gave me some money to get down here. What happened to your face?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about that. Hey, fellas, this here is my mama. These are some of my friends. That's Willie, there's Poker Face, Radio, Cookie, Goldmouth, Biscuit, Jangle Leg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Gibson. Shame on Rayford here for failing to mention that he had such a beautiful mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice to meet you all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How was your train ride?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite comfortable, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Them cookies in there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, oatmeal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Scuse me, you got any batteries on you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a lovely dress. Make it yourself?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely unsettled) Yeah...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PORCH -- DAY Ray and his mama sit in the shade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long, uncomfortable beat. Mama's lip starts to tremble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts some money in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reluctantly, Ray stashes the money in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is a big surprise, mama. I sure didn't expect to see you down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rayford, I wanted so much more for you than this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't cry, mama. This place ain't so bad as it looks. Sure, we work hard, but there's plenty fresh air and sunshine... And you know something else, I've taken to going to church regular. They got services every Sunday right there in the mess hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you lie to me, Rayford. (composing herself) You still have your daddy's watch? (Ray shakes his head) Well, this is all I can give you. I wish it was more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't take that, mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't argue with me. You need it more than I do. I know how a little money can help in a place like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe this. I always said I'd never end up like this. I thought I'd make something of myself, do something with my life. You know, be successful. Have a big house, a family. Now I'm gonna end up just like daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't say that, Rayford. Don't ever say that. He gave up hope. That's where you gotta be different.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They gave me life, mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave you life. And they can't take it away from you. Remember that. You'll get outta here someday. I believe that. You gotta believe it, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TONK HOUSE -- DAY Reclining on a straw mattress, Claude watches intently as Daisy gets dressed. The rickety door reverberates with a loud pounding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude leaps from the bed and slams his fist against the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daisy quickly buttons up her dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Daisy smiles weakly and looks away. She doesn't have much faith in this promise.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Time's up, Banks! We got a crowd gathering out here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Woman came all the way from New York, goddamnit! We'll come out when we're good and ready!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you go see my cousin Maynard like I asked you in my letter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I did. He said he'd file an appeal right away. You didn't tell me he was so good looking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, that side of the family has all the looks and none of the brains. I hope he don't mess things up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He seemed like a pretty good lawyer to me. His offices take up an entire floor of that big, new building on 125th Street, and he was using all these words I never heard before. He even offered me a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A job, huh? Well, that's nice, real nice. You won't have to work long. I'll be back soon enough. After I start work at First Federal Bank of Manhattan, I'll be keeping you in style. Everything will get back to normal again. That's a promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen, Claude, Maynard wanted to know if he should file the appeal on behalf of your friend, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ray Gibson? (thinks about it) No, no. He's the reason I'm in here, Daisy. For all I know, he's got a record a mile long. I got a better shot of getting out of here on my own. You tell Maynard to think about me, concentrate on me. Understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, Claude, whatever you say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY ROAD -- DAY The prisoners jump down from the cart and grab hammers and pick axes as Hoppin' Bob keeps count with pebbles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude jump down after Willie.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We lost yesterday on accounta the rain. That means we gotta make up for it today, so put your backs to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You heard the boss! Let's move!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (squinting at the sun) Looks like a scorcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I bet the son of a bitch goes over a hundred and ten.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take that action.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FIELD -- DAY The long line levels a road to a work tune being sung by Jangle Leg. Dillard checks the thermometer on the truck -- 90 degrees and rising. Mopping his brow, he starts down the line. The sun arcs overhead, a blazing inferno... Heat rises off the road... The men sweat profusely... "Taking it off here, boss!" echoes up and down the line. Biscuit has his work cut out for him, lugging a water bucket from man to man, offering the ladle. The sun... the hammer... the ladle... the axe... the sun... the hammer... the ladle... the axe... The mercury hits 110 degrees...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lets his hammer slip from his fingers, collapses in the dirt. Radio nods to Poker Face, who hands him a pack of cigs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard uses his foot to roll the stricken man over. He's still alive. Barely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude drop their tools, grab the man by his arms and legs and lug him up to the road. Once out of earshot, Ray whispers to Claude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They reach the truck. With effort, they swing the man back and forth and launch him into the back of the truck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Man down, boss!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You two, put him on the truck!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cookie drew me a map to Greenville.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what I'm saying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I know what your saying. And I'm saying if you made it that far, they'd be watching every train that pulls out of that station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's why we won't take the train. Cookie showed me where there's a farm house. They got a boat there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about boats? I bet you can't even swim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I know about boats is they take you to freedom. Come on, man. I think we can do this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why are you always talking about we? There is no we. There is a me, there is a you. But there is no we between us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE WASHROOM -- DAY Ray and Claude continue their conversation as they lather up for a shave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude splits. Scowling, Ray finishes up his shave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You want out of this place, don't you? Don't tell me you're starting to like it here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't like it here. Look around. There's nothing but ass. Male ass! Balls and ass! Believe you me, I'm getting out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does that mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not gonna forget it. What does that mean? If you've got a plan, I think I have a right to know about it. I told you my plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Getting a map from a chubby chef named Cookie? Dragging our asses through the swamps in search of some worm-eaten boat? That ain't a plan, that's a vacation for two in the hole. When you've got a map to New York City, you get back to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- NIGHT Moonlight streams through the barred windows of the cage. Exhausted from the day's work, each man stretches out painfully in his bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Restless, Radio rolls over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Shut up, Claude!" echoes around the room. Irritated, Claude thumps his pillow and turns his back on the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sure was hot out there today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still too hot to sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every bone in my body feel like a big son-of-a-bitch dog got hold of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't wait 'til Sunday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so great about Sunday? Monday's right after it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, what's the name of that nightclub of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean the Boom-Boom Room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. The Boom-Boom Room. Sure would like to see that place when you get it up and running.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should have come by last night, Radio. You woulda had yourself some fun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Last night? What are you talking about, Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm talking about old Satchmo nearly blew the roof off the joint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Satchmo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean Louis Armstrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's a good friend of mine. Drops by the club whenever he's in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, do we have to listen to this bullshit? I'm trying to get some sleep around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, things were hot last night, but you'll never guess who's playing tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ! A high horn note sounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -UP -- Biscuit, all dolled up and flashing a million- dollar smile. She begins to sing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Biscuit is up on a makeshift platform in the bunkhouse, lipsyncing to Ella Fitzgerald. But its not the depressing bunkhouse anymore, it has transformed into Ray's Boom-Boom Room. PULL OUT SLOWLY as Ray, decked out in a sleek tuxedo steps in front of the CAMERA. He speaks into the CAMERA as he walks...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks to his left, sees Goldmouth in the old bunkhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA PANS off Ray to Goldmouth, in a tuxedo, at the front door of the nightclub with two lovely ladies. He waves to himself, sitting on his bunk. Himself waves back, smiling like a kid in a candy store. Willie is behind the bar, serving drinks to three gorgeous SKIMMIES.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A tisket a tasket...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, fellas. Catch any cab heading uptown. All the drivers know Ray's Boom-Boom Room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Hey, Ray...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where am I at, man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in nightclub) C'mon, Goldmouth, somebody's gotta watch the front door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, I could get used to this!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON Cookie sitting a table eating a huge porterhouse. The CAMERA DOLLIES around to find Ray eating with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray motions to a busboy clearing a table. It's Claude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude grimaces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Willie laughing, Goldmouth laughing, Poker Face in the bunk laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Ray at a craps table holding a pair of dice. He looks at Poker Face on his bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK as Ray throws the dice. A perfect seven. The CAMERA PANS UP to Poker Face in a tux clutching a fistful of cash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Across the room, Jangle Leg, in a tux, sits at the piano. Radio, also in a tux, beats on the drums.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Biscuit sings the song, smiling lovingly at her man. Everyone is having a great time in Ray's Boom-Boom Room, until... Whistles blow. At the front door, Hoppin' Bob appears with FIVE TRUSTIES dressed in police outfits. The incorrigibles scatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hard white light from Hoppin' Bob's flashlight shines directly into the CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ray, my man, this steak is like butter!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Made just for you, Cookie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about some steak sauce?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No problem. Oh, boy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about some Worchestershire sauce! And clean that damn table.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, I know you got some gambling!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Poker Face, what's a club without some dice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucky seven! My nigger! Let it ride!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sing, girlfriend!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray, looks like trouble!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON Ray, in his bed, back in the old bunkhouse. The music stops abruptly. He shields his eyes from the harsh light. Hoppin' Bob is looming over him. It's back to reality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A loud burst of flatulence cuts through the darkness. Hoppin' Bob turns his flashlight on Cookie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scowling, Hoppin' Bob steps out of the cage and locks the door behind him. The men slowly settle back in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lights out at Camp 8.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You don't shut up, you're gonna spend the rest of the night in the hole, Gibson! That goes for the rest of you girls, too. I don't want to hear another peep about no Boom-Boom fucking Room!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, Cap'n.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering) Pretty good story, Ray. Didn't much care for the ending though.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 -- YARD -- DAY Claude's playing pepper with Radio, Jangle Leg and Poker Face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The incorrigibles quickly gather around as he calls off names, passing cards and letters through the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard hands the letter to Ray, who glances at it before passing it back to Claude.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mail call!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Craddock!... Williams... Henshaw!... Banks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) Maynard Banks, Esquire. Attorney at law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gimme that. That doesn't concern you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure it don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 BUNKHOUSE -- DAY Claude rips open the letter. A profound disappointment settles over him as he reads the news from cousin Maynard. Bitterly, he crumples up the letter and tosses it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard strolls down the line with his rifle over his shoulder. Under his watchful gaze, hoes rise and fall. After he passes, Claude moves a little closer to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gets in Claude's face and silently mouths the word -- "soft." Claude throws down his hoe and sinks his fist deep into Ray's gut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray touches the blood coming from his nose. Eyes blazing, he tackles Claude, dragging him to the ground. The two men roll around, trying to strangle each other. Hoppin' Bob hustles down the hill and drags Ray off of Claude. But Claude comes back for more. Hoppin' Bob finds himself in the middle of the fray. That's when the cavalry arrives. Two trusties use their rifles to crack Ray and Claude over the backs of their heads, sending them both down for the count. Hoppin' Bob empties his canteen over their faces. They sputter back to consciousness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude stagger to their feet and pick up their tools. Hoppin' Bob and the trusties head back up the hill. Ray starts to chuckle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray opens his palm to reveal TWO PEBBLES. Claude regards Ray with new-found respect.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's up, Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cool) Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure is hot today. Think it'll rain later?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want, Claude?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do I want? What makes you think I want something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daddy always said when a man starts talking about the weather keep you hand on your wallet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your daddy must have been a helluva guy, a deep man, a wise man. Sure wish I could have met him -- RAY Cut the bullshit. What do you want, Claude?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (clearing his throat) You still got that map?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if you're still thinking about booking it, I want in. I think we can make it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We? Did I hear you say we? As I recall, you're the one who said there is no we. Guess we got some bad news in that letter, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, my cousin Maynard is a lawyer. He filed an appeal on my behalf -- RAY On your behalf. What happened to we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The appeal was denied. Then Daisy went and fell for Maynard. They're engaged to be married, can you believe that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's just think about that for a moment. He's a successful lawyer up in New York City and you're down here with a bright future in the cotton picking business. Eeny, meeny, miney, Maynard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, man. Don't shut me out. I'm telling you, you and me, that map, we can go places.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what, Claude? This whole time we've been down here, you've done nothing but think about yourself, acting like this whole thing is my fault. That plan with your cousin, did that include me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least you're honest for once. So now you want to be my friend? Well, let me tell you something, Claude-my- shit-don't-stink-Banks. You got a lot to learn about friendship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does that mean I'm in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so, Claude. You'd just slow me down. We'd have to stop every five minutes so you could polish your silverware. There's no way around it, you're soft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said you're soft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't call me that. You know I hate it when you call me that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn, that felt good. I should have done that the first time I met you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you girls set aside your differences and get back to work or I'll see to it -- RAY -- we'll spend a night in the hole. We heard this shit before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the fuck are you laughing about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRY ROAD -- SUNDOWN One by one, the prisoners of Camp 8 climb into the mule carts under the watchful eye of Hoppin' Bob. As each man passes, he removes a pebble from his pocket. The last one in is Willie. Hoppin' Bob's pocket is now empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard spurs his horse, escorting the mule carts back to camp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All in, boss!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Movin' it out, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FIELD -- SUNDOWN As the carts fade into the distance, Ray and Claude pop up from a roadside ditch and take off for a grove of trees in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WOODS -- SUNDOWN Running for all they're worth, Ray and Claude crash through the bramble. Claude trips over a root and sprawls face first in the bushes. Ray turns around and helps him to his feet. Claude is still laughing giddily. He throws his arms around Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Ray and Claude disappear into the woods...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You did it, man! You got us out! Next stop, New York City!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: New York's a long way's off. Let's just keep moving, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- NIGHT Radio's pulling in some jazz music out of New Orleans. Prisoners hit their bunks as the floorwalker does the nightly head count. He stops at Claude and Ray's empty bunks, glancing around, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DILLARD'S PORCH -- NIGHT Dillard smokes a cigarette on the swing. His wife steps out with a fresh bourbon and ice. Suddenly, SIRENS start to wail and emergency floodlights blaze to life at Camp 8.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FIELD -- NIGHT Hounds scramble down from the back of a truck and gather around the DOG BOY. He holds out a handful of soiled laundry and a dozen snouts sniff it thoroughly. Nearby, Dillard gathers a DOZEN MEN with rifles and flashlights into a posse. He puts a cigarette in his mouth. Hoppin' Bob lights it for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WOODS -- NIGHT Trees rise ominously around Ray and Claude as they push through dense underbrush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude considers it from various angles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray shrugs and presses on. Dumbfounded, Claude considers the map again, then tears it to shreds. The braying of hounds echoes through the trees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know these trees all look the same, but I'm getting an awful familiar vibration from this one right here. You sure you know where we're going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Absolutely. The map is very clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me take a look at that map.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You call this a map? What was Cookie smoking when he drew this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cookie didn't draw it. I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You drew this?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew you wouldn't come if I didn't have a map.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That gripes my soul, man. We're out here in the middle of nowhere. There is shit nibbling at my balls! Don't tell me you don't know where we're going!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, wait up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE WOODS -- NIGHT Ray and Claude race through the underbrush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE WOODS -- NIGHT Dillard and his men follow the dogs through the woods, hot on the scent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE WOODS -- NIGHT Ray and Claude race up to a chain-link fence. On the other side, an old Ford is parked on a dirt road. Hearing the posse closing in behind them, Ray and Claude fling themselves onto the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE WOODS -- NIGHT The posse is gaining ground. Dillard takes two men off to the left, sending the rest of the men straight ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE WOODS -- NIGHT Claude clears the fence first and scrambles for the old Ford. Ray's shirt snags on a piece of wire as he drops down from the fence. Stuck, he dangles helplessly a few feet off the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FORD -- NIGHT Claude yanks open the door and jumps behind the wheel. TWO WHITE TEENAGERS bolt up in the backseat where they were necking. After a beat -- group scream. The half-dressed teenagers dive from the car and scramble off down the road. Claude twists the key in the ignition and the engine roars to life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude sees Ray caught up on the fence, then hears the sounds of the approaching posse. If he floored it right now, he might make it. But he can't just leave Ray hanging there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Ray, time to go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm stuck!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FENCE -- NIGHT Claude runs up and grabs Ray's legs, pulling for all he's worth. The shirt rips free, sending Ray and Claude tumbling to the ground. They leap to their feet and turn toward the car -- running smack into the barrel of Dillard's shotgun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUPERINTENDENT'S MANSION -- DAY An OLD BLACK PRISONER delivers a frosty mint julep to SUPERINTENDENT ABERNATHY who rocks slowly in his chair. At his feet, his 10-year-old daughter MAE ROSE is playing jacks. Her long blonde hair makes her look like a little angel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae Rose is pointing down the drive, where Dillard and a couple of trusties march Ray and Claude toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bound by leg irons and handcuffs, Ray and Claude are deposited at the bottom of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae Rose considers their faces. Ray and Claude look like they've been to hell and back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard nods and turns Ray and Claude around. As they march back down the drive, Abernathy takes sip of his mint julep and affectionately pats Mae Rose on the head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, daddy. They caught those two men who escaped last night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They ain't men, Mae Rose. They're convicts. And nigger convicts to boot. Can you say nigger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nagger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, nigger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nigger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's my girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here they are, Superintendent. We tracked 'em all the way to the Tallahachie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's quite a ways. I'm glad you New York boys could see some of our lovely countryside while you're down here. What do you say, Mae Rose? How should we teach these two a lesson?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A night in the hole?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better make it a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 -- DAY The incorrigibles of Camp 8 gather at the gun line, watching silently as Dillard and a couple of trusties march Ray and Claude toward the hole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- DAY The trusties shove them each into a small, dank cell and slam the doors behind them. Dillard secures both doors with an iron bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: See you in a week, boys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RAY'S CELL -- DAY Ray slumps to the floor, propping his feet against the wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Claude. I just want to say thanks for coming back for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLAUDE'S CELL -- DAY Claude considers his bleak surroundings. It's a small, uncomfortable space, not even big enough to lie down. Just a tin bucket for a toilet.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't mention it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Hell, you'd probably be half way to New York by now...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm serious, man. Don't mention it. Ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- DAY The sun beats down on the tin roofs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- CAGE -- NIGHT The prisoners are gathered around a table, laying out money. As usual, Poker Face is keeping tabs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With an ear to his receiver, Radio slaps his money on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This gives the men pause. Willie tosses his money on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Willie leaves the money where it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poker Face makes notations as the betting resumes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take Claude to die on Wednesday for fifty cents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wednesday for two bits. And don't forget you already owe me a steak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take Claude for Friday. That's my birthday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Weatherman says a heat wave's coming. I say neither one of 'em son of bitches gonna last past Thursday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you before, I don't take pennies. Two cigarettes or one nickel minimum. What about you, Willie? Gonna get in on this action?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got a crispy new dollar bill says both of them gonna make it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now that's what I call a bet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a mighty long shot, Willie. Nobody ever made it a week in the hole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not in August, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who else has some guts around here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FIELD -- DAY Work goes on as usual for the prisoners of Camp 8. Trusties keep their eyes peeled for slackers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- DAY The brick shacks bake in the noonday sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FIELD -- DAY Biscuit moves down the line offering the ladle to the men as they struggle under a crushing heat wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- DAY Superintendent Abernathy strides up and gives the nod to Dillard, who unlocks the doors. Huddled in their respective cells, Ray and Claude shrink from the bright sunlight. Then, slowly and painfully, they rise to their feet. In the background, the incorrigibles gather at the gun line as word spreads that the fellows are still alive. Abernathy glances at the crowd with annoyance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard slams the doors on Ray and Claude and clamps shut the padlocks. Abernathy smiles at the incorrigibles, who regard him with undisguised hatred.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think these boys have learned their lesson. Let's give 'em another week for good measure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure you want to do that, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you ever question me, Sgt. Dillard. When I give an order, you jump to it, or I'll kick you and that first-cousin you call a wife outta that pretty little house so fast it'll make your pin-head spin. You got that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A somber Poker Face offers Willie a wad of bills.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they made it a week. Looks like you win, Willie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let it ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLAUDE'S CELL -- NIGHT A slot at the bottom of the door opens. A tin plate of mush slides through and the slot closes. Slumped in the corner, Claude reaches for the food -- but a RAT beats him to it, scampering out of the shadows and leaping onto the dish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RAY'S CELL -- NIGHT A commotion and wild screams come from Claude's cell. Ray leaps to his feet, shouting through the wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Claude? You alright?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLAUDE'S CELL -- NIGHT Claude continues to stomp the rat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude pounds against the door, raising a holy racket. We continue to cut back and forth between cells as needed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude continues shouting and pounding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks around his cell. Claude's pounding is bound to wake up somebody soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude focuses on what Ray is saying and starts to breathe easier.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can't take it no more, Ray! Die, motherfucker! Gotta get the fuck outta here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep it together, Claude. You wake up the man, he'll shoot you for sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'd be doing me a favor. I'm getting outta here one way or the other! Goddamn rats and shit! Fuck!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, man, just settle down. We'll get outta here, Claude. We'll get outta here real soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How the fuck are we gonna do that, Ray?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll just get off at the next stop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stops pounding, confused) Say what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, we'll get off at the next stop. The train's pulling into the station right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hell you talking about? What train?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're in the Bronx, my man. Hundred and Sixty First Street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hundred and Sixty First Street? That's Yankee Stadium.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, yes, Yankee Stadium. Bombers are playing a double-header against the Red Sox.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Red Sox... Who's on the mound?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Who do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Allie Reynolds. He's my boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, it says Allie Reynolds right here in the program. He's warming up right now. Man, we're so close to the field I need cleats. How'd you get such good seats?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They must be the right people. Whoa, there goes the hot dog man. Let's get a couple. Damn, that smells good. Nothing like a ballpark hot dog, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You get ketchup?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ketchup? Who eats ketchup on a hot dog? Mustard's what you want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't eat it with mustard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- NIGHT Dillard strides toward the hole, shotgun in hand. He pauses to listen to the argument, cocking an eyebrow in befuddlement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard shakes his head, shoulders his gun and heads back toward his house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Give me back that hot dog. I'll eat it myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off) What am I gonna eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off) You can starve to death for all I care. Now shut up, the game's about to start.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Hey, man, is Babe Ruth in the lineup today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Of course, he's in the lineup. There he goes right there. Hey, Babe...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- DAY Abernathy gives the nod to Dillard, who unlocks the doors. Two trusties drag Ray and Claude out of their cells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- DAY The men crowd around the windows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's going on? Are they alive or dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't look too good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're not moving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE HOLE -- DAY Slowly, Claude opens his eyes, squinting in the harsh light of day. Summoning his strength, he staggers to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray's eyes blink open. Claude holds out a hand and helps him stand up. They share a look. They made it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abernathy turns on his heels. Dillard considers the two tough guys standing before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude stagger toward the bunkhouse as the incorrigibles gather on the porch and help them in out of the sun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ray...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (scowling) Sergeant Dillard, make sure these two are out in the fields first thing in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, get inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- TIME PASSAGE (Note: This montage is mixed with 16mm and Super 8 footage. A beautiful 1940s song plays over.) A. King Kong is machined-gunned off the top of the Empire State Building... B. FDR introduces his New Deal... C. The incorrigibles chop weeds... D. With Willie and Claude standing guard, Ray samples a batch of moonshine from a secret still in his footlocker... E. At the height of the depression, poor people line up in front of a soup kitchen... F. Ray and the crew sit around the poker table playing cards and laughing... G. Ray opens a letter and pulls out a snapshot of his mama which he places over his bunk. H. The incorribles level a road... I. Jesse Owens wins the 100 meter race at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin... J. Benny Goodman sets the kids dancing with wild abandon in the aisles of the Paramount Theater... K. The Hindenburg bursts into flames... L. Claude writes a letter, "Dear Sylvia"... M. In the juke joint, Sylvia reads the letter and smiles. She shows it to a few other WORKING GIRLS... N. Adolf Hitler stabs the air in front of a foreboding sea of Nazis... O. The 1939 World's Fair opens in New York... P. Ray nails a sign to the side of the bunkhouse: RAY'S BOOM BOOM ROOM. He steps back to admire the effect. Behind him, Sylvia and her friends mingle with the incorrigibles in the yard... Dillard takes his cut as Claude and Sylvia head for the tonk house. Ray and his date step up... Q. Lou Gehrig is honored at Yankee Stadium. "Today I consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the Earth..." R. With a pillow stuffed under a home-made Santa outfit, Ray distributes chocolate to the incorrigibles while Claude and Willie decorate the saddest little Christmas tree you ever saw. S. The 1940 Oldsmobile is introduced... T. Japanese Zeros bomb Pearl Harbor... U. FDR declares "a day that will live in infamy."... V. A WWII newsreel shows American G.I. s storming a beach in the South Pacific...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The inmates of Camp 8 cheer for the American soldiers up on a makeshift movie screen. Instead of black and white stripes, the prisoners now wear blue twill. In an audience of new faces, the CAMERA FINDS some familiar ones. Ray and Claude are surrounded by their crew -- Willie, Radio, Poker Face, Cookie, Biscuit, Jangle Leg and Goldmouth. A decade has passed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY A line of NEW PRISONERS stands before Dillard, now 10 years older.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard pauses in front of a big country boy who can't be more than 18 years old. The kid is bouncing a rubber ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kid don't answer. An OLD GUY steps forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Camp 8 is for incorrigibles, so whatever you've done to get here, believe me, we are not impressed. You new men are probably noticing that we have no fences here at Camp 8. We don't need no fences, we have the gun line. It runs from shack to shack clear around the yard --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell you think you're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, boss. That kid don't talk. Something wrong with his head, just can't get right, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't get right, huh? We'll see how long he last. Now, where was I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't need no fences at Camp 8, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. We don't need no fences, we have the gun line. It runs from shack to shack clear around the yard. You are now inside the gun line...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- DAY Ray and some of the fellas are playing poker. Dillard's voice drifts in through the open window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lays down his cards and rakes in the pot.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (mouthing along) If you step outside the gun line without my permission, you will be shot. If you trip and fall over the gun line, you will be shot. If you spit, if you pee, if you stick your ass out and take a dump over the gun line, you will be shot...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BASEBALL FIELD -- DAY Jangle Leg pitches to Radio, who swings and misses. Behind the plate, Goldmouth tosses the ball back to Jangle Leg. On the sideline, Ray teaches three-card monte to CAN'T GET RIGHT. Claude paces nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another pitch, another strike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Radio knocks a grounder up the middle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right looks at Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right shuffles to the plate. Goldmouth hands him the bat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jangle Leg tosses the ball. Can't Get Right swings and connects with a mighty CRACK! The incorrigibles crane their necks as the ball disappears into the sky. They turn to look at Can't Get Right. Ray gives Claude a significant look, then tosses another ball out to Jangle Leg on the mound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jangle Leg nods, winds up and delivers a whistling fast ball. Can't Get Right clobbers it. Once again, the incorrigibles track the departing projectile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right smiles for the first time.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I try to teach 'em the finer points of the game, share my wisdom, but I don't know why I bother. They don't listen, they sure don't learn...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What you're dealing with here is a complete lack of talent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sick of watching Camp 12 win the championship. Every year they get to roast the victory pig and we get dick. This year I want that pig.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, Radio, there you go. Who wants to hit next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to hit? (to Claude) Yo, Claude. Give Can't Get Right a shot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (skeptical) Him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't be worse than any of these other fools.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, grab the bat. Let's see what you can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jangle Leg's gonna throw the ball nice and easy. You just go ahead and take a swing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Let's try that again. This time give it a little juice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Told ya.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SUPERINTENDENT'S MANSION -- DAY The men of Camp 8 paint a fence along the drive leading up to the big house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then a U. S. Army Jeep swerves past the men and parks in front of the mansion. Young CAPT. TOM BURNETTE helps MAE ROSE out of the car. The prisoners stare furtively at her long legs and curly blonde tresses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next to them, Can't Get Right stares openly, mesmerized by her beauty. Ray nudges him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up at the mansion, Abernathy and his WIFE come out onto the porch, all smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners steal glances as Mae Rose kisses her new husband goodbye. She gives them quite a show, raising her leg behind her just like Betty Grable. Then Tom climbs into the Jeep and pulls away. Mae Rose takes a long glance at the prisoners. The men all look away -- except Can't Get Right who stands there smiling innocently. Mae Rose gives him a little wink, then turns her back and bounces up the steps.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I heard Camp 12 got themselves a son- of-a-bitch used to pitch for the Mud Hens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That boy got a year for jay-walking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Judge must have money riding on the championship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't matter who Camp 12 puts on the mound. All I know is when this season's over Camp 8's gonna have pork chops.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like little Mae Rose has grown up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mmm-mm, that girl's got gams.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's got it all. And it's firm and round and fully packed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You shred it, wheat. That there is fresh water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be cool, man. You can look, just don't drool.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How was the honeymoon? Am I gonna be a grandaddy soon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . ABERNATHY Don't pay attention to the superintendent, Tom. You're going to stay for supper, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Afraid not. I'm shipping out this afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BASEBALL FIELD -- DAY A plump PIG roots about in a small pen. A sign dangles from a post -- "First Prize." The incorrigibles of Camp 8 limber up for the big game with the inmates of Camp 12 across the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beyond the fence, a late-model sedan rolls up. STAN BLOCKER, in a straw hat and a rumpled suit, climbs out and stretches his legs. Irritated, he smacks a mosquito and exchanges a few words with Dillard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude hustles over, removing his hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blocker winks at Dillard, then glances at the incorrigibles practicing in the field. Goldmouth, Cookie, Poker Face, Biscuit -- they don't exactly inspire confidence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blocker takes a seat on the bench.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Think you can handle something that big, Cookie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I handled your mama, didn't I? Don't y'all worry. I got plans for that bad boy. Ain't none of him going to waste.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Banks! Get over here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Stan Blocker. Scout for the Nigger Leagues.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Negro Leagues, actually. Pittsburgh Crawfords. Ever hear of us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We get the games on the radio sometimes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We played down in Jackson yesterday. Heard a rumor you've got a boy up here who can hit the ball a ton.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You probably mean Can't Get Right. That's him over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't Get Right? That's the kid's name? Can I talk to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can try, but you won't get too far. Why you interested?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Crawford's are always looking for new talent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you didn't notice, but this is a prison.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are ways around that. Right sergeant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice looking squad. See you after the game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BASEBALL FIELD -- DAY The inmates of Camp 12 are in the field. Our boys from Camp 8 cheer for Cookie digging in at the plate. Ray taunts the opposition from the third base line. The PITCHER winds up and releases a fast ball. Cookie swings and connects for a base hit up the middle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Abernathy and Mrs. Dillard share a box of Cracker Jack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mae Rose sits next to them. She is SIX MONTHS PREGNANT. She removes her sunglasses and coyly bites a fingernail when she spots Can't Get Right in the on-deck circle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . ABERNATHY Of course, the superintendent's hoping for a boy, but personally, I'd prefer a girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DILLARD Whatever it is will be a little gift from heaven. Look at the way she glows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right smiles shyly. Sensing trouble, Claude ushers Can't Get Right toward the plate, massaging his shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right digs in. Claude returns to the sidelines and appeals to the gods. The pitcher winds up and releases a fast ball. Can't Get Right connects with that familiar CRACK! Blocker stands up and watches the ball clear the fence and just keep going. With his team cheering him on, Can't Get Right trots around the bases. But he's still looking at Mae Rose.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're my boy, just keep what little mind you have focused on the game. If you hit that ball the way I know you can, you might just be our ticket off this farm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Cookie slowly turns the pig on a spit over an open fire. The incorrigibles are savoring a victory feast. As always, trusty guards keep an eye on things. Off to the side, Blocker is laughing with Ray and Claude. He takes a hit off Ray's bottle of shine. It's not his first, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blocker starts for his car, parked just beyond the gun line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude's eyes gleam with hope as Blocker's car rumbles off down the road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mark my words, within five years there's gonna be a colored man playing in the majors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, the world hasn't changed that much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe not yet. But it will. And I'll be out of a job. Damn, that's some tasty hooch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's amazing what Ray here can do with a couple of pounds of potato skins and some molasses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, Blocker, what do you think of our boy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think that boy could be the next Josh Gibson. I'm gonna talk to the front office about him, you can bet on that. Damn, it's getting late. We got a game in Memphis tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about us? Don't forget to mention us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're like his handlers. He can't function without us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll put in a good word for you. You've done a good job with that boy. Thanks for your hospitality.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SUPERINTENDENT'S MANSION -- NIGHT Inside, a woman screams in agony. Then, the HEALTHY CRIES of a new-born baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAE ROSE'S BEDROOM -- NIGHT Superintendent Abernathy paces anxiously in front of a white curtain surrounding Mae Rose's bed. Suddenly, Mrs Abernathy staggers out from behind the curtain with a stricken look on her face. She tries to speak, but words fail her. Her legs go wobbly and she faints dead away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The DOCTOR steps from behind the curtain, drawing it behind him. He checks Mrs. Abernathy's pulse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abernathy pushes past the doctor and yanks open the curtain. Mae Rose is propped up in bed, looking exhausted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The NURSE turns around, cradling the baby in her arms. Abernathy gently pulls back the soft blanket. His eyes widen with horror upon discovering that the newest member of the Abernathy family is black.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, doctor...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She'll be fine. She just had a bit of a shock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Mae Rose okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's doing just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the baby?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vague) He's a big one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a boy! Well, let's get a look at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, where is he? Where's my new grandson?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY Can't Get Right bounces his rubber ball off the wall, catching it on the rebound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE CAGE -- DAY Ray passes around his latest batch of buck as the men discuss Can't Get Right's professional prospects. The thump-thump of the ball on the wall outside plays over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You really think they'll let him out of here just to play baseball?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? Boy's got God-given talent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God may have given it, but Claude Banks spotted it and nurtured it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn straight. I expect those Pittsburgh Crawdads to remember that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Crawfords.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glancing out the window) Heads up, here comes trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY Abernathy drives his sedan up to the bunkhouse. All of his worldly possessions are strapped to the roof. It appears that the Abernathys are leaving town. In the back seat, Mae Rose cradles her baby. Her mother sits next to her. Dillard steps out into the yard to confer with the Superintendent, then turns to address the inmates.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Alright, listen up! I want every man lined up out here in the yard on the double! Let's move it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You heard what the man said! Move it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY Abernathy holds his newborn grandson up next to Ray's face. Hmm. Scowling, he moves a little further down the line, scrutinizing the features of each man. He pauses in front of Claude, holds up the baby. Maybe. Abernathy stops in front Goldmouth. Holds up the baby. The possibility makes him shudder. He moves on to Can't Get Right. His eyes narrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disgusted, Abernathy hands the baby back to Mae Rose. Then he turns, walks back to Can't Get Right and places a revolver against his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right nods slowly. Abernathy smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up and down the line, the men brace themselves for the worst. Can't Get Right just grins. Enraged, Abernathy cocks the revolver. That's when Ray steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stunned, Abernathy lowers the gun and approaches Ray. Then Claude steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Confused, Abernathy looks back and forth between the two men. Then Willie steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so it goes down the line, until every last man of Camp 8 has stepped forward to claim kinship with the Superintendent. Even hard-ass Dillard can't help cracking a smile. Disgusted, confused and thoroughly fed up, Abernathy jams the revolver into his belt and climbs into the car. As he guns the engine, Mae Rose gazes out the back window, smiling one last time at the father of her baby. Can't Get Right smiles back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know it was somebody from this camp. I can feel it in my bones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who the father of that little chocolated baby is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then, who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The baby's mine, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's lying, boss. I'm the father of that baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Actually, it was me, boss. I know I may look old...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Any fool could see that baby's mine, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I beg to differ. That cute little rascal belongs to me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the father...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the father, boss...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the father...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm the father...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY It's visiting Sunday and Ray's Boom Boom Room is in full swing. Sylvia's girls are everywhere. Down at the gunline, Dillard takes his cut from inmates lined up for their turn in the tonk. A FIVE-PIECE PRISON BAND is playing the blues. Nearby, Willie is dispensing Ray's moonshine from a bunkhouse window. He raises a jar in a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The incorrigibles erupt in boisterous agreement. Claude grabs Can't Get Right and shakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just then, Rev. Clay and his daughter emerge from the mess hall and start across the yard. It's a good thing the old man is blind because he wouldn't want to see how far his flock has strayed. The Reverend inhales deeply as one of Sylvia's girls passes nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blissed out incorrigibles enjoy a last dance as the band downshifts into a slow, sultry number. In the midst of the dancers, Claude clings to Sylvia. Nearby, Jangle Leg dances intimately with a YOUNG WOMAN. Up on the porch, Ray refreshes Biscuit's drink. Biscuit has been crying and it shows. The liquor probably isn't helping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls some folded sheets of paper from his pocket, passes them to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poker Face leans in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray gives Poker face a shove, then turns back to Biscuit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray hands back the papers and heads off to dance with a PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN lingering nearby. Left alone, Biscuit polishes off his moonshine and checks his reflection in the bunkhouse window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crumples the discharge papers and drops them. Then he steps down from the porch and walks calmly past the dancing prisoners toward the gun line. Ray lifts his head off his date's shoulder. Something about the way Biscuit is walking suggests that he isn't going to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's too late. Biscuit crosses the gun line and keeps walking, his eyes focused on the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The band stops playing, the dancers grow still. Dillard turns around and squints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Biscuit isn't paying attention. He breaks into a run. Dillard nods to Hoppin' Bob who raises his rifle and draws a bead. But he can't pull the trigger. He lowers his gun. Shots ring out from the shooter shacks. Biscuit reels from the impact of the bullets and looks down sadly at the blood spreading across his ring-arounds... Prisoners silently gather at the gunline. Jangle Leg pushes his way through the crowd and crosses the gunline without hesitation. Dillard indicates for the shooters to hold their fire. They train their rifles on Jangle Leg as he strides toward his fallen companion. Jangle Leg gently lifts Biscuit's lifeless body into his big arms and somberly carries him back toward the camp. The CAMERA RISES HIGH OVERHEAD as the prisoners make way for Jangle Leg to cross back over the gunline.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: To Superintendent Abernathy. May he have many more grandchildren!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I want to know is where? When? How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wasting your breath, Claude. He ain't the type to kiss and tell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CLAY There's a sweet fragrance in the air today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The magnolias are blooming early this year, daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't take it so hard, Biscuit. She don't mean nothin' to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell with him. It ain't that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are free papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (devastated) What am I gonna do out there, Ray? I can't go home to my mama like this. I'll get the strap for sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Biscuit, this is good news. Your mama's gonna break down in tears when you show up on her doorstep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sotto) I'll give you three to one she gives him the strap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's 1945. It's a different world now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not for me, it ain't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well you can't stay here, Biscuit. This ain't no life for a man. Any one of these fellas would give their right arm to be in your shoes. I sure know I would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No life on the inside, no life on the outside...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Biscuit...!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man over the line!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamnit, Biscuit, get back here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUNKHOUSE -- DAY A dark mood hangs over the men. Jangle Leg sits stoically as Radio fiddles with his receiver. Nearby, Poker Face and Ray play a listless game of gin rummy. Claude is thumbing distractedly through a dog-eared copy of Baseball Digest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But nobody can muster much enthusiasm for this news. Radio shrugs and drops down on his bunk. Just then, Can't Get Right walks past heading for the door. He's dressed in civilian clothes, his bindle slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right holds out a piece of paper which Ray scrutinizes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The incorrigibles gather around for a glimpse at Can't Get Right's ticket to freedom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right nods out the window. Stan Blocker is waiting by his car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, fellas, I got Chicago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Can't Get Right, where you going? Why you dressed like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a pardon from the governor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me see that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where'd you get this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY Claude storms across the yard and stops at the gun line. Ray is a few steps behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This hits Claude hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude looks around as the incorrigibles begin to gather. He's on the spot. Dillard approaches with Can't Get Right. Claude looks into the big kid's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steeling himself to the reality of the situation, Claude gives Can't Get Right a hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right nods. He steps up to the gun line and looks at both shooter shacks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't Get Right steps across the gun line. Blocker opens the car door for him. But before he climbs in, Can't Get Right reaches into his pocket and pulls out his rubber ball. With a smile, he tosses it to Claude, who snatches it out of the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blocker tips his hat and climbs behind the wheel. Claude and Ray watch Blocker's car drive off under a red Mississippi sunset. Slowly, the inmates drift back toward the bunkhouse until Ray an Claude are left alone at the gun line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly enraged, Ray hauls off and knocks Claude down with a solid right. Surprised, Claude touches his bloody lip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hard look comes to Ray's eyes as Claude rises to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray walks away, leaving Claude to nurse his split lip.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yo, Blocker, what's going on here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Kid's getting out. I got him a pardon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, but what about me and Ray? I didn't see our names on that pardon. You said you were gonna put in a good word for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did, Claude. I mentioned you. I mentioned you both. But the fact is, pardons don't come cheap. The kid can hit. What can you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let it go, Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not gonna let it go. The man needs to explain himself. Makin' promises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I am truly sorry about this. I'd like to help you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least the kid's getting out. Isn't this what you wanted?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (resigned) Yeah. Of course it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You show them Crawfords how to play ball.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make 'em throw strikes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's alright. You're a free man now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, we'll take good care of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One of the new kids said they're farming those acres just north of the swamp. He said he saw a crop duster flying around the place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not in the mood right now, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said they keep it parked out behind the barn. Can't be that hard to fly a plane. Lots of people do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're called pilots! I'm serious, Ray. I'm not in the mood for one of your stupid, fucked-up plans right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see you coming up with any plans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting mad) My plan is on his way to Pittsburgh right now. That congenital idiot just got himself a pardon signed by the governor thanks to us, but we can't seem to do nothing for ourselves. Don't you feel a little disgusted right now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Crop duster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I ain't getting in no airplane with you. I'm finally wrapping my mind around the concept. They threw us in this shithole for life. Don't you get it, Ray? We're gonna die here! Might as well head up to the cemetery, pick a plot and start digging.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My daddy died in prison. He gave up hope and hung himself. What you're talking about is the same damn thing. That ain't how I'm going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you're fooling yourself, Ray. Maybe you're just a chip off the old block.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take that back or we ain't friends no more, Claude Banks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's a news flash, Ray. We never were friends. We've just been stuck together for 12 years. It's been nothing but bad luck since the moment I ran into you. Every time I look at you I get sick to my stomach thinking about what my life could have been if I'd never bumped into Ray Gibson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better watch yourself Claude, before you say something you regret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The only thing I regret is the day I met you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if that's the way it is...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the way it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I have nothing left to say to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never said nothing of value anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- TIME PASSAGE A. In his Pittsburgh Crawfords uniform, Can't Get Right lays into a fast ball, sending it soaring into the bleachers... B. People dance in the street in Time Square, marking the end of WWII... C. Hoppin' Bob drops a package on Ray's bunk. Ray rips off the brown paper to reveal a book: "So You Want to Learn to Fly..." D. Claude and Sylvia make love in the tonk house... E. In the mess hall, Ray pointedly carries his tray past a table where Claude sits with Willie... F. An A-bomb explodes in the Bikini Atolls... G. Jimmy Stewart hugs his wife and children at the end of "It's a Wonderful Life"... H. Jackie Robinson slides across home plate at Ebbets Field... I. Ray runs full tilt across a field toward a barn. Sure enough, there's the single engine crop duster parked right where he said it would be... J. Claude and another INMATE repair a hole in the bunkhouse roof. They dive for cover as Ray's crop duster swoops low overhead and dips out of sight beyond the trees. A puff of smoke rises into the sky... K. Soot-stained, Ray is marched to the hole and shoved inside... L. Newly elected president Harry Truman holds up a copy of the Chicago Tribune baring the headline "Dewey Defeats Truman"... M. RCA unveils the first color television... N. Cars pull up next to speaker poles in front of a drive-in movie screen... O. In the bunkhouse, early rock and roll plays on a modern 1950s radio that sits where the old vacuum tube receiver used to be. A YOUNG TOUGH now occupies Radio's old bunk... P. At the poker table, Poker Face slumps forward onto his pile of chips, revealing a straight flush. The other men quickly fold... Q. With a TRUSTY standing guard, Claude and Ray silently shovel dirt into Poker Face's grave. The CAMERA MOVES past gravemarkers -- Biscuit, Jangle Leg, Radio... R. Marilyn Monroe's skirt rises on a blast of subway air in "The Seven-Year Itch"... S. Rosa Parks is arrested for refusing to sit in the back of the bus... T. Elvis Presley creates a sensation on the Ed Sullivan Show... U. School children learn to "duck and cover" in the event of nuclear attack... V. The inmates of Camp 8 work to level a road. Ray's on one side, Claude's on the other... W. Prisoners mingle with friends and family on visiting Sunday. Claude waits on the bunkhouse steps. His face brightens when Sylvia appears... X. Blacks sit-in at lunch counters in Greensboro, N.C... Y. Kennedy is elected... Z. OMITTED...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Martin Luther King delivers his "I have a dream" speech at the Lincoln Memorial...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The Zapruder footage of Kennedy being shot...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . American soldiers jump down from helicopters and run for the jungles in Vietnam...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Ford introduces the 1965 Mustang...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The assassination of Malcolm X...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Muhammad Ali looms over Sonny Liston, asking "What's my name?"...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The CAMERA MOVES past more gravemarkers -- Hoppin' Bob, Goldmouth -- to find Claude and Ray silently shoveling dirt over another casket. Ray pounds a simple marker into the ground: Cookie. Briefly, they lock eyes. But neither one speaks and the moment passes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Go-Go dancers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mao Tse Tung...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jimi Hendrix at the Monterey Pop Festival...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TV's Batman and Robin battle the forces of evil in Gotham City...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Black Panthers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Peace Protesters...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The death of Martin Luther King...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Robert Kennedy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Neil Armstrong sets foot on the moon...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Vida Blue rears back and fires a pitch in the 1972 World Series...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY On the porch, Willie, now in his 70s, sits in a wheelchair watching the ball game on a black-and-white television. A TRUSTY waits nearby. Ray, now in his mid-60s, emerges from the bunkhouse lugging a duffle bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives Willie a slap on the back and nods to the trusty. The trusty wheels the old man across the yard where YOUNG PRISONERS mingle with WIVES and FAMILY MEMBERS sporting the fashions of the early '70s -- Afros, mutton chops, paisley prints and bell-bottom pants.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Alright Willie, I think I got everything. I'll talk to Dillard, see if I can get up to the infirmary and check up on you. Make sure they're changing your diapers regular.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll be sending you up there soon enough. And not just for a visit, neither.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (leaning in) I slipped in a couple of bottles of my latest batch. Help wash down all them pills they'll be giving you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looking old-style, Claude sits on the mess hall steps waiting for Sylvia. He catches Willie's eye. The two men nod to each other, an unspoken farewell. Then Claude turns to find Ray looking at him from the bunkhouse steps. Ray and Claude hold each others gaze for a moment. Then Ray heads back into the bunkhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude turns to face YVETTE, a pretty young woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude takes this in, staring off into space.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (off) Are you Claude Banks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Yvette. Sylvia sent me. You look just like she said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's alright, isn't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, she's fine. She's just not coming today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She got married last month.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Married?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Real nice guy, too. Trumpet player. They moved down to New Orleans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She always said that if you were on the outside...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I'm not on the outside. I'm in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue
