dialogue.raw_text: I know she's sorry she won't be seeing you anymore. Anyway, she wanted me to take care of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take care of me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, go to the tonk or whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm too old for you. Besides, I'm not much in the mood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want me to come back some other time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Nice girl like you don't belong in a place like this. But if you talk to Sylvia, tell her old Claude said congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY Claude stands at the gun line, staring across at the Dillard house. Mrs. Dillard places a couple of pies on the windowsill to cool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, he makes a break for the Dillard house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray turns to see Claude dashing across no-man's land. Shots ring out from the shooter shack, kicking up dirt around Claude's feet as he serpentines across the field.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Whites-only pies...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Man over the line!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DILLARD'S HOUSE -- DAY Breathless, Claude makes it to the kitchen window and digs his hand into the golden-brown crust, shoving a sloppy fistful of pie into his mouth. More shots ring out. Bullets PING all around him. Grabbing the pie, he darts around the side of the building, out of range. Back against the wall, he drops down on his haunches, snarfing pie like a hungry wolf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY A case of empty Coke bottles sits in the middle of the yard, glinting in the hot sun. His face smeared with boysenberry, Claude finishes taking off his boots and socks and steps barefoot onto the bottles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a trusty's rifle and moves among the inmates, who have gathered around. He stops when he gets to Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray glances at Claude, then back at Dillard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dillard offers the rifle to Ray, who doesn't have to think too long.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Comfortable?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As a pair of fur-lined bedroom slippers, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll see what those slippers feel like after, say, 24 hours. And if you step down off them bottles -- if one toe so much as touches the dirt -- one of these boys is gonna shoot you dead. Let's see. We need a special man for this job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about it, Ray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll make you trusty right now. If that pie-eatin' son of a bitch falls off those bottles and you have to shoot him, I'll see to it you get a pardon. Hell, I'll personally escort you out the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't want to give me a gun, boss. I'm liable to use it on you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- SUNDOWN Ray's been given the same treatment as Claude. Barefoot, balanced on Coke bottles, the two men stand a few feet apart facing each other. A trusty with a rifle keeps an eye on them. After years of silence, the tension reaches the breaking point...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The trusty tightens his grip on his rifle. He'd love the opportunity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stand in stony silence. Then Ray starts to laugh. A long, low belly laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two men start to laugh. Really laugh. Nearly a decade's worth of laughter comes welling up out of them, and they nearly lose their balance, which only makes them laugh harder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're a sucker. I'd have taken that deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me? Are you talking to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd have knocked you off those bottles, put a bullet in your ass and be half way to New York right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After all these years of blissful silence, I almost forgot how annoying the sound of your voice can be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you don't think I owe you anything. Because I don't owe you a damn thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't do if for you, anyway. I just ain't no boot-licking trusty, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was sorry to hear about your mama passing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was five years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but since we're talking, I thought I'd mention it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not talking, you're talking, and doing too damn much of it, if you ask me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You sure looked funny running for those pies, bullets flying all around you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bullets weren't the problem. That pie was too hot. Burned my tongue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAMP 8 YARD -- DAY A trusty bangs the rap iron. Young prisoners pour from the bunkhouse and line up for breakfast. Claude and Ray bring up the rear, the elder statesmen of the bunch. By a long shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude and Ray step out of line and approach Dillard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray and Claude share a look. Then Ray embraces Dillard, who stoically endures the breach of his personal space.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fourteen acres today and only 12 hours of daylight! Eat up and move it out! Gibson! Banks! Get your sorry asses over here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every morning I wake up praying that Ray Gibson and Claude Banks have died in their sleep and every morning you disappoint me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I stand before you a defeated man. Try as I might, I can't seem to break you. I swear, if they dropped a nuclear bomb on this camp, you and the cockroaches would be the only things left. But starting today at least I won't have to endure your presence any longer. You've got fifteen minutes to clear out your footlockers. You're both being reassigned to the Superintendent's mansion. And I, for one, will not miss you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I always wanted to do that. (sighing) There is so much love inside of this man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SUPERINTENDENT'S MANSION -- DAY Up on the porch, Claude brings a tray of minted iced tea to Superintendent Wilkins, who sets aside his bible and washes down a couple of pills. Before going back inside, Claude can't resist taunting Ray, busy trimming a hedge out in the hot sun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yard boy, these pansies could use some attention over here. Perhaps some fertilizer would restore their exuberance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MARSH -- DAY Claude and Ray beat the bulrushes with switches, rustling a couple of pheasants from their hiding spot. As the birds take wing, Wilkins aims his shot gun and fires twice in rapid succession. Both birds fall from the sky in a flutter of feathers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SUPERINTENDENT'S MANSION -- DAY Claude fills Wilkins' water glass as the Superintendent takes a bite of lamb chop and winces in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude glances at a glossy brochure. From outside, Ray peers suspiciously through the dining room window as he hacks at a rose bush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude returns the brochure.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Damn dentures slipping again. Everything falls apart when you grow old, eh, Claude? Time sure marches on.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ocean views, palm trees, two heated swimming pools and a golf course -- sounds a damn sight better than that infirmary across the way where I'm gonna end up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I apologize, Claude. That was rude of me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's alright, boss. Takes a lot more than a colorful brochure to hurt my feelings.

dialogue.raw_text: You been on the farm for quite a spell, haven't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over forty years now. Me and Ray Gibson out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forty years. That's a long time for any crime, even murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a hell of a lot longer when you're innocent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Half the men in this prison swear they're innocent. Don't you think that's kinda funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have to forgive me if I don't laugh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SERVANTS' QUARTERS -- NIGHT Ray and Claude are getting ready for bed.

dialogue.raw_text: You and Wilkins sure are getting chummy. You two planning on going steady, or something?

dialogue.raw_text: He's just a lonely old man. He likes to talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, I'm a lonely old man. I like to talk, too. So why don't we start by talking about what kind of a plan you're working on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not working on a plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't fool me, Claude. I know you got something brewing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Ray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SUPERINTENDENT'S MANSION -- DAY Ray hacks a rose bush down to the nub. From the garage comes the sound of an engine turning over. Wilkins' 1973 Lincoln Continental convertible lurches down the drive with Claude at the wheel. He screeches to a halt inches from Ray's legs and climbs from the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude pulls out a hanky and buffs Ray's finger print off the hood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray scowls as Claude straightens his chauffeur uniform and heads up the path to the mansion.

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't touch that car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wilkins' driver's got the flu, so he asked me to fill in for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't driven in 40 years, you ain't even got a license. Man's taking his life in his hands, putting you behind the wheel! Where you taking him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Greenville. We're picking up the new Superintendent at the bus station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GREENVILLE BUS STATION -- DAY Claude pulls up in front of the station, steps out of the car and holds the door for Wilkins, who checks his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilkins heads into the station, leaving Claude alone with the Continental. All around him are the sights, sounds and smells of the free world. A woman rushes into the arms of a man as he climbs off a bus. Across the street is Grandma Dodi's Pork Rib Joint where Cookie never made it to the peach cobbler. A young brother with a boom box walks by. In the street, kids crowd around the back of an ice cream truck. Then Claude catches his reflection in the car window and frowns. When did he get this old? Unnerved, he moves around to the back of the car and pops open the trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray looks, Claude clocks him. Ray slumps back into the trunk. Claude stuffs Ray's legs back into the trunk and slams the lid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up just as Wilkins and the new superintendent exit the bus station. Warren Pike's hair has gone grey and he's 40 years older, but there's no mistaking the former sheriff of Natchez County. He still bears a nasty scar on his cheek from a wound inflicted long ago.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know I trust you, Claude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be right back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting up) Damn, it was getting hot in there.

dialogue.raw_text: If somebody deserves respect, Mr. Pike, they receive it from me, convict or no convict.

direction.raw_text: . MARSH -- DAY Claude and Ray beat the bullrushes with switches. Amid a flutter of wings, three pheasants take to the air. Wilkins fires first, knocking one out the sky. Pike pulls off two rounds, playing clean up.

direction.raw_text: . FIELD -- DAY Ray and Claude dump their game bags into the back of a pickup truck. Nearby, Pike drains his flask while Wilkins scrapes mud off his boots. The breeze picks up, clouds fill the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pike pulls a gold watch from his pocket and releases the face plate. A familiar mechanical tune floats on the gathering breeze. Ray turns around slowly. His eyes fall on the watch in Pike's hand. His daddy's watch. In Pike's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude looks at the watch, then at Ray. Uh oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pike thrusts the barrel of his gun up under Ray's chin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilkins turns to see Pike holding Ray at gunpoint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray grabs the barrel of the shotgun and slams it into Pike's face. Pike rolls over and freezes, staring down the barrel of his own gun now in Ray's hands. Confused, Wilkins points his gun at Ray.

direction.raw_text: Claude grabs for the gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude yanks the gun free and points it right in Pike's face. Wilkins trains his gun on Claude. But the moment passes. Claude lowers the gun. Bewildered, Wilkins does the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ray mouths the word -- "soft." Claude clenches his jaw, points the gun and pulls the trigger. Click. Pike smirks and pulls a small gun from his boot. But as he raises it -- BLAM! Pike is hurled backward by a shotgun blast. Shocked, Ray and Claude look at Wilkins, his gun still smoking in his hands. After a significant beat, Ray reaches down and gingerly retrieves his daddy's gold pocket watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INFIRMARY -- NIGHT The building is dark. But then, through a first-floor window, we see the unmistakable orange glow of a fire.

direction.raw_text: . INFIRMARY -- NIGHT Ray dodges flames as he presses into the inferno.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INFIRMARY -- NIGHT Nurse Humphries, Willie and the rest of the inmates watch grimly as flames engulf the building. Nobody could survive this blaze. From the highway comes the siren wail of approaching fire engines. But it's too late. Sparks erupt into the night sky as the roof collapses...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INFIRMARY -- DAWN Fire trucks pull away from the smoldering ruins. A local REPORTER interviews witnesses. INVESTIGATORS comb through the wreckage, making notes. COUNTY CORONERS pull a couple of gurneys from the back of their van.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INFIRMARY RUINS -- DAY Superintendent Bill Burke is led through the destruction by a FIRE INSPECTOR. They approach the coroners as they finish zipping up two body bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burke watches solemnly as the coroners wheel the bodies past him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How did it start?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Probably old wires. The place was a tinderbox just waiting to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess we should have torn this old building down a long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gibson made it this far before he was probably overcome by smoke. From the look of things, Banks never even made it out of bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PRISON CEMETERY -- DAY Jake and Leon shake their heads and look at the two fresh graves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young inmates share a look, then glance into the graves, then look back at Willie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leon and Jake do the arithmetic. You can almost hear the gears grinding under the strain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie starts to chuckle and sets his electric wheel chair on auto-pilot, leaving the young inmates to guess at the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They pick up their shovels and go back to work burying the caskets.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Man, you really bummed me out. That's a terrible story. (looking at Jake) Nigger, you crying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell, no! I just got something in my eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's alright for a man to cry once in awhile. Just don't make a habit of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Willie, what was Claude's plan, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing to it, really. Claude figured they could steal a couple of bodies from the morgue. They got a couple of crackers working there don't know their asses from their elbows. Then they was gonna set fire to the infirmary and make it look like those bodies was them that got stuck inside. Claude figured during the commotion, it wouldn't be too hard to slip onto one of the fire trucks and hang tight until it rolled right on out of here in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What makes you think it didn't work?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never said it didn't work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You trying to tell us that's not Ray and Claude in those boxes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think that old man lost his marbles about a hundred years ago. Come on, let's get this over with.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GREENVILLE FIRE STATION -- DAY The CAMERA MOVES PAST a FIREMAN hosing down the truck, past another group of soot-stained FIREMEN eating breakfast, and pauses in front of two lockers. A couple of FIREMEN emerge from the showers wrapped in towels and open their lockers. They share a look.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 (to the room) Alright, which of you hambones took our clothes?
dialogue.name: dialogue
